front.p: 1843 September 1: Octavius Hadfield to his mother Amelia Hadfield (nee White)

body.p: I have a few minutes to write in & as I hear there is a vessel going direct to England, I gladly employ them in writing to you. I have been much gratified since I last wrote, which was to Henry, by receiving several letters from hom: from Amelia, my father, Octavia, & George. Receiving them all at one time, you were all brought very forcibly before my mind; & I received great delight from it. I also received a letter from Alick. You appeared all to be tolerably well when those letters were written & I trust this will find you so. I have to thank I believe George for news-papers, which are interesting. I was rather unwell when I last wrote: & have been worse since; but am now well again. I cannot do so much work now as I used some time ago: but I am not quite left to myself now: though my fellow-workers know but little of the language of the natives.

The natives are going on quietly & steadily; & I lately was joined by almost all the remnant of the heathen party, at Otaki & the neighbourhood. These people have resisted me in every possible way during nearly four years: & now they openly confess that their object in doing so was to induce me to leave them in disgust; but that having watched us, the christian party, during so long a period, they are compelled to acknowledge, that we are in possession of some principles, whose tendencies are more conducive to order & good conduct - they our enemies being our judges - than any with which they were acquainted. The people at Waikanae have built a very beautiful church, which is now almost complete; & which is much admired. They have been engaged nearly two years at it, & have worked well & altogether gratuitously.

I am now going to build myself a house at Waikanae, as my old mud-house is decaying fast & excessively damp, & the cause of hindering my work, as it is not fit for a European residence. I have been careful not to spend more of the Society's money than is necessary; but I find a man gets no credit for it, & that if one does not take care of oneself, there is nobody here to take care of one. Many who have come much since I have & have never done any work, are living in good houses. Economy may be carried too far, & some of my medical friends here tell me that I shall soon be able to do no work at all if I do not take care of myself. I merely mention this, because whilst I have been protesting against the extravagance of this mission I may be accused of taking care of myself as well as others taking care of themselves.

My friends here are very kind; & nobody could be more constantly kind & attentive than my dear friends the St Hills, with whom I am now for a day or two, having money matters to attend to here. I return to-day to Waikanae, & as I must go about twenty miles, I must put an end to my writing. Give my kindest love to all at home & kindest regards to all friends &
